meanings.definition: To bite or chew on something repeatedly
meanings.sent1: The puppy likes to gnaw on his favorite toy.
meanings.sent2: The beaver will gnaw on wood to build its dam.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel decided to gnaw on the acorn instead of burying it.
meanings.sent4: Time seemed to gnaw away at the old wooden fence, slowly breaking it down.
meanings.sent5: The termite infestation continued to gnaw at the foundation of the house, causing damage.

meanings.definition: To wear away or erode gradually
meanings.sent1: The constant dripping water will gnaw at the rock over time.
meanings.sent2: The river's current can gnaw away at the riverbank, changing its shape.
meanings.sent3: The wind and rain work together to gnaw at the mountain, shaping it over centuries.
meanings.sent4: The rust began to gnaw at the metal gate, causing it to weaken.
meanings.sent5: The waves gnaw at the shore, slowly reshaping the coastline.

meanings.definition: A persistent feeling of worry or anxiety
meanings.sent1: The gnaw of anxiety in her stomach made it hard to focus.
meanings.sent2: The gnaw of worry about the test kept him up at night.
meanings.sent3: The gnaw of concern about the presentation made her practice even more.
meanings.sent4: The gnaw of fear in his mind prevented him from taking risks.
meanings.sent5: The gnaw of unease in the room was palpable, making everyone tense.
